sub_title: Managing Director IMAPP at Radboud University
summary: Enthusiastic team player | Effective organizer with analytic skills | Proficient in presenting results to a broad international audience | Experienced in writing policy reports | Project management | Full professional proficiency in English and professional working proficiency in German

school.name: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University

projects.title: Soehngen Institute of Anaerobic Microbiology
projects.description:
To help build a sustainable economy on new anaerobic micro-organisms. This is the proposal that earned a group of leading Dutch microbiologists a Gravitation grant (Zwaartekrachtsubsidie) from the Ministry of Education, Culture & Science. Prof. Mike Jetten from Radboud University Nijmegen and fellow-scientists from TU Delft, Wageningen University and the Royal Netherlands Institute for Sea Research (NIOZ) will use the funding to set up SIAM, an institute to identify new anaerobic-living micro-organisms with characteristics that will benefit the environment and health. Gravitation grants are intended to provide excellent Dutch scientific fields with the funding they need to carry out top level research.

The microbiologists in the SIAM (Soehngen Institute for Anaerobic Microbiology) consortium are tackling one of the greatest challenges facing our society: creating a sustainable economy based on biomass. Microbes that survive without oxygen will play an important role, whether they live alone or in complex microbiological communities. They have many important functions, such as producing biogas, for example, turning organic waste into degradable bioplastics or improving health by optimising the microflora in the gut. Micro-organisms can also be used to trap or even neutralise greenhouse gases. SIAM will search for as yet unidentified anaerobic microbes, while also focusing on training a new generation of microbiologists.

authors.headline: Managing Director IMAPP at Radboud University

profile_positions.description: The Institute for Mathematics, Astrophysics and Particle Physics (IMAPP) is focusing on the origin and evolution of the universe and its underlying mathematical structures. IMAPP is involved in different national and international research programs making use of state of the art equipment and observatories and contributes to the development of new applications. BSc and MSc courses are developed and lectured by IMAPP scientists. In addition, IMAPP is actively engaged in outreach. As managing director of IMAPP I use my enthusiasm for science and management to create new possibilities for research, education and innovation.
profile_positions.title: Managing Director IMAPP

profile_positions.description:
Institute for Water and Wetland Research
Department of Microbiology

The Soehngen Institute of Anaerobic Microbiology (SIAM) is a new and challenging research program, established by the Universities Nijmegen, Wageningen, Delft, and the Royal NIOZ research institute. This program is funded by a Gravitation grant; a grant financed by the Dutch Ministry of Education, Culture and Science to encourage excellent research.

The main goal of the SIAM Program is to discover new anaerobic microorganisms, design synthetic microbial communities, and use those insights and results for the development of sustainable applications contributing to a bio based economy. 

As coordinator of the SIAM program, I will secure and manage this organization. In addition, I will promote the program, facilitate the development of summer schools and courses to educate young scientists, and organize face-to-face meetings for SIAM scientists to get the very best out of this collaborative effort.
profile_positions.title: Coordinator of SIAM Gravitation Program

profile_positions.description:
German Research Centre for Environmental Health
Research Unit Environmental Genomics (EGEN)

In this department, the effects of microbial communities on health and the environment are investigated using the -omics toolbox. See also: http://www.helmholtz-muenchen.de/egen. I focused on N-cycle bacteria, more specifically: denitrifying microorganisms. Using next generation sequencing and in silico analysis, the regulation of microbial denitrification in soil was studied.
profile_positions.title: Research Scientist

profile_positions.description:
Institute of Technical Biochemistry

The MWK Biosynthesis Project is funded by the Ministry of Science, Research and Arts of Baden Württemberg (Germany) and is a cooperation between the Universities of Stuttgart, Tübingen and Ulm and the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology. The aim of this project is to develop sustainable products and materials using biosynthesis. My main responsibilities were: financial planning & reporting, organizing face-to-face meetings and administrative tasks. http://www.bwbiosyn.de/view/home.php

In addition to my job as Program Officer, I was involved in a genomics project. Here, we investigated a biochemical pathway towards herbicide removal. A draft genome was obtained and published in Genome Announcements (May 2015, DOI: 10.1128/genomeA.00420-15).
profile_positions.title: Program Officer of the MWK Biosynthesis Project

profile_positions.description:
Institute for Water and Wetland Research
Department of Microbiology

In this period as a Postdoc the feasibility of using M. oxyfera in a novel way of wastewater treatment was investigated further (follow-up of PhD project described below). 

In February 2012, I started working on a project funded by an ERC Proof of Concept-grant. Here, I focused on the commercialization of low temperature wastewater treatment. This work was in collaboration with the Department of Environmental Science (Radboud University Nijmegen) for life cycle assessment studies and the company Paques BV, The Netherlands.

In addition, a grant proposal was written and submitted to the Dutch Technology Foundation (STW) to investigate a novel way of wastewater treatment using M. oxyfera and Anammox bacteria. The proposal, including 1 postdoc and 2 PhD positions, was awarded in November 2013.
profile_positions.title: Postdoctoral Fellow

profile_positions.description:
Institute for Water and Wetland Research
Department of Microbiology

Thesis: Applied aspects of nitrite-dependent methane oxidation

This PhD project focused on the applied aspects of nitrite-dependent methane oxidation by ‘Candidatus Methylomirabilis oxyfera’. M.oxyfera is an interesting candidate microorganism to be applied in a more sustainable way of wastewater treatment. This research was published in several peer reviewed journals.
profile_positions.title: PhD candidate

volunteer_experiences.description: I was responsible for the financial situation of the PhD council.  Together with the chair and secretary of the PhD council, I was representing the Nijmegen PhD candidates in meetings with the governing body of the University and the dean. The PhD council conducted a survey (2008) among PhD candidates of the Radboud University. As a result, the international office improved their policy in assisting foreign PhD candidates with administrative matters and a checklist was made and signed by the dean to support education and supervision of PhD candidates. See: http://www.ru.nl/pon/pon/phd-surveys/

volunteer_experiences.role: Chair of the competition committee and certified youth sail trainer
volunteer_experiences.description: As chair of the competition committee, I was responsible for the organization of local sailing competitions with about 100 participants. One of my key tasks was managing different sub-committees to make these sailing events a success. In addition, I am a certified youth sail trainer accepted by the Dutch Sailing Federation (KNWV). A yearly educational program was developed, including a sailing summer camp for children.
